entry.title: A New Rehabilitation City for War Heroes

media:group.media:title: A New Rehabilitation City for War Heroes
media:group.media:description:
A rehab center called "Rehabilitation City of Heroes" is being built in the Proshyan community near Yerevan. It will be the first of its kind in Armeniaโค The projectโs goal is to carry out psychological, intellectual and social rehabilitation treatments for wounded soldiers and war survivors in general.
Suren Areents is the author of the project and he believes that physical wounds are not the deepest ones that soldiers experience.

entry.title: โWe have to do everything to ensure that the new generation succeedsโ, Marie Lou Papazian

media:group.media:title: โWe have to do everything to ensure that the new generation succeedsโ, Marie Lou Papazian
media:group.media:description:
Marie Lou Papazian, in conversation with Lara Tcholakian, speaks about her source of energy and optimism, as well as her sense of perseverance and grit. She touches upon the memories of her family history and family narratives, and how her grandparents helped shape her successful journey. She reflects on the perspectives required for a viable Armenia and Artsakh, and shares her vision for a hopeful future for Armeniaโs children.
About Marie Lou Papazian Marie Lou Papazian is TUMOโs founding CEO. As an engineer and education specialist, she has led the Education for Development Foundation linking Armenian students to their global peers through online educational activities. Previously, she was lead construction manager on prominent high-rise buildings in New York City. Marie Lou holds a Masterโs Degree in Computing in Education from the Teachers College at Columbia University and is a graduate of Harvard Business Schoolโs General Management Program. In 2019, she received the Ordre des Palmes acadรฉmiques โ a national order bestowed by the French Republic on distinguished academics and figures in the world of culture and education.
Program overview Armenian leaders share inherited cultural and historical narratives, memories, life learnings and experiences. Down-to-earth, authentic and mindful conversations preserve the stories and legacies of families, and reflect on the lessons learnt from inherited collective trauma and introspective leadership.

During the last 20 years, the area of wheat fields and the total harvest has been cut in half in Armenia. The level of self-sufficiency, which shows the percent of demand that the country is able to meet with its own production, is at a low 24.4%. This means that Armenia imports the remaining wheat it uses from abroad.

entry.title: US House passes pro Armenia amendment, demandings release of Armenian POWs

media:group.media:title: US House passes pro Armenia amendment, demandings release of Armenian POWs
media:group.media:description:
The US House of Representatives passed the Cardenas-Schiff-Sherman Amendment demanding the release of Armenian POWs currently captive in Azerbaijan.
Armenian Foreign Minister Ararat Mirzoyan has called for a return to the Armenia-Azerbaijan peace process under the auspices of the OSCE Minsk Group.

entry.title: From Italy to Armenia: Life as a Journalist

media:group.media:title: From Italy to Armenia: Life as a Journalist
media:group.media:description:
Intern Teresa di Mauro looks back at her time in Armenia where she worked with the CivilNet team as a journalist. Teresa discusses her report which looked at three Italians who had made the city of Gyumri their home. She also touches upon her plans to return to Armenia in the future.
